Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the mother needs to prepare for it
Situation2: They notice minor inconsistencies in a building plan that are unlikely to cause immediate issues.
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the lines blurring as my mind wandered. The numbers from the home loan statement echoed in my head—two months until the next payment, and I needed to make sure we were covered. My son’s school fees, groceries, the electricity bill—every expense seemed to weigh heavier than the last. As a mother, I felt the pressure to keep our home secure, to never let my family feel the uncertainty I carried.

But as I traced the lines of the building plan, I noticed small inconsistencies. Nothing catastrophic, but enough to make me pause. As an architect, I was expected to ensure every detail was safe and compliant, no matter how minor. Fixing these would mean extra hours, maybe even delaying the project, and risking the bonus I was counting on for the loan. My supervisor expected efficiency, my family expected stability, and I was caught in the middle, heart pounding, torn between the demands of my two worlds.
